title: Quantum computers are better at guessing, new study demonstrates
summary:
Title: Quantum Computers Show Promise in Solving Complex Problems, Despite Noise

Introduction:
Quantum computers offer advantages in solving complex problems, but they are highly susceptible to errors or noise. This poses a challenge in obtaining real-world advantages in the current "noisy" state of quantum computing, known as the NISQ era. Noise reduction is crucial for any demonstration of quantum speed advantage.

Quantum Speed Advantage:
Researchers conducted a study using a game-like scenario to evaluate computer performance. They replaced words with bitstrings, and a classical computer required approximately 33 million guesses to identify a 26-bit string. In contrast, a perfectly functioning quantum computer, utilizing a quantum algorithm developed over 25 years ago, could identify the correct answer in just one guess. However, noise significantly affects this exponential quantum advantage.

Noise Suppression Technique:
The researchers achieved a quantum speedup by employing a noise suppression technique called dynamical decoupling. Initially, the technique seemed to degrade performance, but after refinements, the quantum algorithm functioned as intended. The time to solve problems then grew more slowly than with any classical computer, with the quantum advantage becoming more evident as the problems became more complex.

Quantum Solution vs. Classical Computers:
Although classical computers can currently solve the problem faster in absolute terms, the reported advantage is measured in terms of the time-scaling it takes to find the solution. This means that for longer bitstrings, the quantum solution will eventually be quicker. The study demonstrates that, with proper error control, quantum computers can execute complete algorithms with better time-scaling than conventional computers, even in the NISQ era.
